trans-unit.source: Use Azure Premium Storage with SQL Server on Virtual Machines
trans-unit.target: Use Azure Premium Storage with SQL Server on Virtual Machines

trans-unit.source: This article provides guidance for how to start using Azure Premium Storage with SQL Server running on Azure Virtual Machines. This includes examples of new deployments and migrations of existing deployments of SQL Server on IaaS.
trans-unit.target: This article provides guidance for how to start using Azure Premium Storage with SQL Server running on Azure Virtual Machines. This includes examples of new deployments and migrations of existing deployments of SQL Server on IaaS.

trans-unit.source: Use Azure Premium Storage with SQL Server on Virtual Machines
trans-unit.target: Use Azure Premium Storage with SQL Server on Virtual Machines

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Azure Premium Storage</linkText><title></title></link> is the next generation of storage that provides low latency and high throughput IO.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Azure Premium Storage</linkText><title></title></link> is the next generation of storage that provides low latency and high throughput IO.

trans-unit.source: It works best for key IO intensive workloads, such as SQL Server on IaaS <link><linkText>Virtual Machines</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: It works best for key IO intensive workloads, such as SQL Server on IaaS <link><linkText>Virtual Machines</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: This article provides planning and guidance for migrating a Virtual Machine running SQL Server to use Premium Storage.
trans-unit.target: This article provides planning and guidance for migrating a Virtual Machine running SQL Server to use Premium Storage.

trans-unit.source: This includes Azure infrastructure (networking, storage) and guest Windows VM steps.
trans-unit.target: This includes Azure infrastructure (networking, storage) and guest Windows VM steps.

trans-unit.source: The example in the <link><linkText>Appendix</linkText><title></title></link> shows a full comphrensive end to end migration of how to move larger VMs to take advantage of improved local SSD storage with PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: The example in the <link><linkText>Appendix</linkText><title></title></link> shows a full comphrensive end to end migration of how to move larger VMs to take advantage of improved local SSD storage with PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: It is important to understand the end-to-end process of utilizing Azure Premium Storage with SQL Server on IAAS VMs.
trans-unit.target: It is important to understand the end-to-end process of utilizing Azure Premium Storage with SQL Server on IAAS VMs.

trans-unit.source: This includes:
trans-unit.target: This includes:

trans-unit.source: Identification of the prerequisites to use Premium Storage.
trans-unit.target: Identification of the prerequisites to use Premium Storage.

trans-unit.source: Examples of deploying SQL Server on IaaS to Premium Storage for new deployments.
trans-unit.target: Examples of deploying SQL Server on IaaS to Premium Storage for new deployments.

trans-unit.source: Examples of migrating existing deployments, both stand-alone servers and deployments using SQL AlwaysOn Availability Groups.
trans-unit.target: Examples of migrating existing deployments, both stand-alone servers and deployments using SQL AlwaysOn Availability Groups.

trans-unit.source: Possible migration approaches.
trans-unit.target: Possible migration approaches.

trans-unit.source: Full end-to-end example showing Azure, Windows, and SQL Server steps for the migration of an existing AlwaysOn implementation.
trans-unit.target: Full end-to-end example showing Azure, Windows, and SQL Server steps for the migration of an existing AlwaysOn implementation.

trans-unit.source: For more background information on SQL Server in Azure Virtual Machines, see <link><linkText>SQL Server in Azure Virtual Machines</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more background information on SQL Server in Azure Virtual Machines, see <link><linkText>SQL Server in Azure Virtual Machines</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Author: Daniel Sol
trans-unit.target: Author: Daniel Sol

trans-unit.source: Technical Reviewers: Luis Carlos Vargas Herring, Sanjay Mishra, Pravin Mital, Juergen Thomas, Gonzalo Ruiz.
trans-unit.target: Technical Reviewers: Luis Carlos Vargas Herring, Sanjay Mishra, Pravin Mital, Juergen Thomas, Gonzalo Ruiz.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites for Premium Storage
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites for Premium Storage

trans-unit.source: There are several prerequisites for using Premium Storage.
trans-unit.target: There are several prerequisites for using Premium Storage.

trans-unit.source: Machine Size
trans-unit.target: Machine Size

trans-unit.source: For using Premium Storage you will need to use DS series Virtual Machines (VM).
trans-unit.target: For using Premium Storage you will need to use DS series Virtual Machines (VM).

trans-unit.source: If you have not used DS Series machines in your cloud service before, you must delete the existing VM, keep the attached disks, and then create a new cloud service before recreating the VM as DS* role size.
trans-unit.target: If you have not used DS Series machines in your cloud service before, you must delete the existing VM, keep the attached disks, and then create a new cloud service before recreating the VM as DS* role size.

trans-unit.source: For more information on Virtual Machine sizes, see <link><linkText>Virtual Machine and Cloud Service Sizes for Azure</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on Virtual Machine sizes, see <link><linkText>Virtual Machine and Cloud Service Sizes for Azure</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Cloud Services
trans-unit.target: Cloud Services

trans-unit.source: You can only use DS* VMs with Premium Storage when they are created in a new cloud service.
trans-unit.target: You can only use DS* VMs with Premium Storage when they are created in a new cloud service.

trans-unit.source: If you are using SQL Server AlwaysOn in Azure, the AlwaysOn Listener will refer to the Azure Internal or External Load Balancer IP address that is associated with a cloud service.
trans-unit.target: If you are using SQL Server AlwaysOn in Azure, the AlwaysOn Listener will refer to the Azure Internal or External Load Balancer IP address that is associated with a cloud service.

trans-unit.source: This article focuses on how to migrate while maintaining availability in this scenario.
trans-unit.target: This article focuses on how to migrate while maintaining availability in this scenario.

trans-unit.source: A DS* Series must be the first VM that is deployed to the new Cloud Service.
trans-unit.target: A DS* Series must be the first VM that is deployed to the new Cloud Service.

trans-unit.source: Regional VNETS
trans-unit.target: Regional VNETS

trans-unit.source: For DS* VMs you must configure the Virtual Network (VNET) hosting your VMs to be regional.
trans-unit.target: For DS* VMs you must configure the Virtual Network (VNET) hosting your VMs to be regional.

trans-unit.source: This “widens” the VNET is to allow the larger VMs to be provisioned in other clusters and allow communication between them.
trans-unit.target: This “widens” the VNET is to allow the larger VMs to be provisioned in other clusters and allow communication between them.

trans-unit.source: In the following screenshot, the highlighted Location shows regional VNETs, whereas the first result shows a “narrow” VNET.
trans-unit.target: In the following screenshot, the highlighted Location shows regional VNETs, whereas the first result shows a “narrow” VNET.

trans-unit.target: <linkText>RegionalVNET</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You can raise a Microsoft support ticket to migrate to a regional VNET, Microsoft will make a change, then to complete the migration to regional VNETs, change the property AffinityGroup in the network configuration.
trans-unit.target: You can raise a Microsoft support ticket to migrate to a regional VNET, Microsoft will make a change, then to complete the migration to regional VNETs, change the property AffinityGroup in the network configuration.

trans-unit.source: First export the Network Configuration in PowerShell, and then replace the AffinityGroup property in the VirtualNetworkSite element with a Location property.
trans-unit.target: First export the Network Configuration in PowerShell, and then replace the AffinityGroup property in the VirtualNetworkSite element with a Location property.

trans-unit.source: Specify Location = XXXX where XXXX is an Azure region.
trans-unit.target: Specify Location = XXXX where XXXX is an Azure region.

trans-unit.source: Then import the new configuration.
trans-unit.target: Then import the new configuration.

trans-unit.source: Storage Accounts
trans-unit.target: Storage Accounts

trans-unit.source: You will need to create a new storage account that is configured for Premium Storage.
trans-unit.target: You will need to create a new storage account that is configured for Premium Storage.

trans-unit.source: Note that the use of Premium Storage is set at the storage account, not on individual VHDs, however when using a DS* Series VM you can attach VHD’s from Premium and Standard Storage accounts.
trans-unit.target: Note that the use of Premium Storage is set at the storage account, not on individual VHDs, however when using a DS* Series VM you can attach VHD’s from Premium and Standard Storage accounts.

trans-unit.source: You may consider this if you do not want to place the OS VHD on to the Premium Storage account.
trans-unit.target: You may consider this if you do not want to place the OS VHD on to the Premium Storage account.

trans-unit.source: The following New-AzureStorageAccountPowerShell command with the "Premium_LRS" Type creates a Premium Storage Account:
trans-unit.target: The following New-AzureStorageAccountPowerShell command with the "Premium_LRS" Type creates a Premium Storage Account:

trans-unit.source: VHDs Cache Settings
trans-unit.target: VHDs Cache Settings

trans-unit.source: The main difference between creating disks that are part of a Premium Storage account is the disk cache setting.
trans-unit.target: The main difference between creating disks that are part of a Premium Storage account is the disk cache setting.

trans-unit.source: For SQL Server Data volume disks it is recommended that you use ‘Read Caching’.
trans-unit.target: For SQL Server Data volume disks it is recommended that you use ‘Read Caching’.

trans-unit.source: For Transaction log volumes, the disk cache setting should be set to ‘None’.
trans-unit.target: For Transaction log volumes, the disk cache setting should be set to ‘None’.

trans-unit.source: This is different from the recommendations for Standard Storage accounts.
trans-unit.target: This is different from the recommendations for Standard Storage accounts.

trans-unit.source: Once the VHDs have been attached, the cache setting cannot be altered.
trans-unit.target: Once the VHDs have been attached, the cache setting cannot be altered.

trans-unit.source: You would need to detach and reattach the VHD with an updated cahce setting.
trans-unit.target: You would need to detach and reattach the VHD with an updated cahce setting.

trans-unit.source: Windows Storage Spaces
trans-unit.target: Windows Storage Spaces

trans-unit.source: You can use <link><linkText>Windows Storage Spaces</linkText><title></title></link> as you did with previous Standard Storage, this will allow you to migrate a VM that is already utilizing Storage Spaces.
trans-unit.target: You can use <link><linkText>Windows Storage Spaces</linkText><title></title></link> as you did with previous Standard Storage, this will allow you to migrate a VM that is already utilizing Storage Spaces.

trans-unit.source: The example in <link><linkText>Appendix</linkText><title></title></link> (step 9 and forward) demonstrates the Powershell code to extract and import a VM with multiple attached VHDs.
trans-unit.target: The example in <link><linkText>Appendix</linkText><title></title></link> (step 9 and forward) demonstrates the Powershell code to extract and import a VM with multiple attached VHDs.

trans-unit.source: Storage Pools were used with Standard Azure storage account to enhance throughput and reduce latency.
trans-unit.target: Storage Pools were used with Standard Azure storage account to enhance throughput and reduce latency.

trans-unit.source: You might find value in testing Storage Pools with Premium Storage for new deployments, but they do add additional complexity with storage setup.
trans-unit.target: You might find value in testing Storage Pools with Premium Storage for new deployments, but they do add additional complexity with storage setup.

trans-unit.source: How to find which Azure Virtual Disks Map to Storage Pools
trans-unit.target: How to find which Azure Virtual Disks Map to Storage Pools

trans-unit.source: As there are different cache setting recommendations for attached VHDs, you might decide to copy the VHDs to a Premium Storage account.
trans-unit.target: As there are different cache setting recommendations for attached VHDs, you might decide to copy the VHDs to a Premium Storage account.

trans-unit.source: However, when you reattach them to the new DS series VM, you might need to alter the cache settings.
trans-unit.target: However, when you reattach them to the new DS series VM, you might need to alter the cache settings.

trans-unit.source: It is simpler to apply the Premium Storage recommended cache settings when you have separate VHDs for the SQL Data files and log files (rather than a single VHD that contains both).
trans-unit.target: It is simpler to apply the Premium Storage recommended cache settings when you have separate VHDs for the SQL Data files and log files (rather than a single VHD that contains both).

trans-unit.source: If you have SQL Server data and log files on the same volume, the caching option you choose depends on the IO access patterns for your database workloads.
trans-unit.target: If you have SQL Server data and log files on the same volume, the caching option you choose depends on the IO access patterns for your database workloads.

trans-unit.source: Only testing can demonstrate which caching option is best for this scenario.
trans-unit.target: Only testing can demonstrate which caching option is best for this scenario.

trans-unit.source: However if you are using Windows Storage Spaces which are made up of multiple VHDs you will need to look at your original scripts to identify which attached VHDs are in what specific pool, so you can then set the cache settings accordingly for each disk.
trans-unit.target: However if you are using Windows Storage Spaces which are made up of multiple VHDs you will need to look at your original scripts to identify which attached VHDs are in what specific pool, so you can then set the cache settings accordingly for each disk.

trans-unit.source: If you do not have original script available to show you which VHDs map to the storage pool, you can use the following steps to determine the disk/storage pool mapping.
trans-unit.target: If you do not have original script available to show you which VHDs map to the storage pool, you can use the following steps to determine the disk/storage pool mapping.

trans-unit.source: For each disk, use the following steps:
trans-unit.target: For each disk, use the following steps:

trans-unit.source: Get list of disks attached to VM with the Get-AzureVM command:
trans-unit.target: Get list of disks attached to VM with the Get-AzureVM command:

trans-unit.source: Get-AzureVM -ServiceName <html></html> -Name <html></html> | Get-AzureDataDisk
trans-unit.target: Get-AzureVM -ServiceName <html></html> -Name <html></html> | Get-AzureDataDisk

trans-unit.source: Note the Diskname and LUN.
trans-unit.target: Note the Diskname and LUN.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>DisknameAndLUN</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>DisknameAndLUN</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Remote desktop into the VM.
trans-unit.target: Remote desktop into the VM.

trans-unit.source: Then go to Computer Management | Device Manager | Disk Drives.
trans-unit.target: Then go to Computer Management | Device Manager | Disk Drives.

trans-unit.source: Look at the properties of each of the ‘Microsoft Virtual Disks’
trans-unit.target: Look at the properties of each of the ‘Microsoft Virtual Disks’

trans-unit.source: <linkText>VirtualDiskProperties</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>VirtualDiskProperties</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The LUN number here is a reference to the LUN number you specify when attaching the VHD to the VM.
trans-unit.target: The LUN number here is a reference to the LUN number you specify when attaching the VHD to the VM.

trans-unit.source: For the ‘Microsoft Virtual Disk’ go to the Details tab, then in the Property list, go to Driver Key.
trans-unit.target: For the ‘Microsoft Virtual Disk’ go to the Details tab, then in the Property list, go to Driver Key.

trans-unit.source: In the Value, note the Offset, which is 0002 in the following screenshot.
trans-unit.target: In the Value, note the Offset, which is 0002 in the following screenshot.

trans-unit.source: The 0002 denotes the PhysicalDisk2 that the storage pool references.
trans-unit.target: The 0002 denotes the PhysicalDisk2 that the storage pool references.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>VirtualDiskPropertyDetails</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>VirtualDiskPropertyDetails</linkText>

trans-unit.source: For each storage pool dump out the associated disks:
trans-unit.target: For each storage pool dump out the associated disks:

trans-unit.source: Get-StoragePool -FriendlyName AMS1pooldata | Get-PhysicalDisk
trans-unit.target: Get-StoragePool -FriendlyName AMS1pooldata | Get-PhysicalDisk

trans-unit.source: <linkText>GetStoragePool</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>GetStoragePool</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Now you can use this information to associate attached VHDs to Physical Disks in Storage Pools.
trans-unit.target: Now you can use this information to associate attached VHDs to Physical Disks in Storage Pools.

trans-unit.source: Once you have mapped VHDs to Physical Disks in Storage Pools you can then detach and copy them over to a Premium Storage account, then attach them with the correct cache setting.
trans-unit.target: Once you have mapped VHDs to Physical Disks in Storage Pools you can then detach and copy them over to a Premium Storage account, then attach them with the correct cache setting.

trans-unit.source: Please see the example in the <link><linkText>Appendix</linkText><title></title></link>, steps 8 through 12.
trans-unit.target: Please see the example in the <link><linkText>Appendix</linkText><title></title></link>, steps 8 through 12.

trans-unit.source: These steps show how to extract a VM-attached VHD disk configuration to a CSV file, copy the VHDs, alter the disk configuration cache settings, and finally redeploy the VM as a DS series VM with all the attached disks.
trans-unit.target: These steps show how to extract a VM-attached VHD disk configuration to a CSV file, copy the VHDs, alter the disk configuration cache settings, and finally redeploy the VM as a DS series VM with all the attached disks.

trans-unit.source: VM Storage Bandwidth and VHD Storage Throughput
trans-unit.target: VM Storage Bandwidth and VHD Storage Throughput

trans-unit.source: The amount of storage performance depends on the DS* VM size specified and the VHD sizes.
trans-unit.target: The amount of storage performance depends on the DS* VM size specified and the VHD sizes.

trans-unit.source: The VMs have different allowances for the number of VHDs that can be attached and the maximum bandwidth they will support (MB/s).
trans-unit.target: The VMs have different allowances for the number of VHDs that can be attached and the maximum bandwidth they will support (MB/s).

trans-unit.source: For the specific bandwidth numbers, see <link><linkText>Virtual Machine and Cloud Service Sizes for Azure</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For the specific bandwidth numbers, see <link><linkText>Virtual Machine and Cloud Service Sizes for Azure</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Increased IOPS are achieved with larger disk sizes.
trans-unit.target: Increased IOPS are achieved with larger disk sizes.

trans-unit.source: You should consider this when you think about your migration path.
trans-unit.target: You should consider this when you think about your migration path.

trans-unit.source: For details, <link><linkText>see the table for IOPS and Disk Types</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For details, <link><linkText>see the table for IOPS and Disk Types</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Finally, consider that VMs have different maximum disk bandwidths they will support for all disks attached.
trans-unit.target: Finally, consider that VMs have different maximum disk bandwidths they will support for all disks attached.

trans-unit.source: Under high load, you could saturate the maximum disk bandwidth available for that VM role size.
trans-unit.target: Under high load, you could saturate the maximum disk bandwidth available for that VM role size.

trans-unit.source: For example a Standard_DS14 will support up to 512MB/s; therefore, with three P30 disks you could saturate the disk bandwidth of the VM.
trans-unit.target: For example a Standard_DS14 will support up to 512MB/s; therefore, with three P30 disks you could saturate the disk bandwidth of the VM.

trans-unit.source: But in this example, the throughput limit could be exceeded depending on the mix of read and write IOs.
trans-unit.target: But in this example, the throughput limit could be exceeded depending on the mix of read and write IOs.

trans-unit.source: New Deployments
trans-unit.target: New Deployments

trans-unit.source: The next two sections demonstrate how you can deploy SQL Server VMs to Premium Storage.
trans-unit.target: The next two sections demonstrate how you can deploy SQL Server VMs to Premium Storage.

trans-unit.source: As mentioned before, you do not necessarily need to place the OS disk onto Premium storage.
trans-unit.target: As mentioned before, you do not necessarily need to place the OS disk onto Premium storage.

trans-unit.source: You might choose to do this if you are intending to place any intensive IO workloads on the OS VHD.
trans-unit.target: You might choose to do this if you are intending to place any intensive IO workloads on the OS VHD.

trans-unit.source: The first example demonstrates utilizing existing Azure Gallery Images.
trans-unit.target: The first example demonstrates utilizing existing Azure Gallery Images.

trans-unit.source: The second example shows how to use a custom VM image that you have in an existing Standard storage account.
trans-unit.target: The second example shows how to use a custom VM image that you have in an existing Standard storage account.

trans-unit.source: These examples assume that you have already created a Regional VNET.
trans-unit.target: These examples assume that you have already created a Regional VNET.

trans-unit.source: Existing Deployments that do not use AlwaysOn Availability Groups
trans-unit.target: Existing Deployments that do not use AlwaysOn Availability Groups

trans-unit.source: For existing deployments, first see the <link><linkText>Prerequisites</linkText><title></title></link> section of this topic.
trans-unit.target: For existing deployments, first see the <link><linkText>Prerequisites</linkText><title></title></link> section of this topic.

trans-unit.source: There are different considerations for SQL Server deployments that do not use AlwaysOn Availbility Groups and those that do.
trans-unit.target: There are different considerations for SQL Server deployments that do not use AlwaysOn Availbility Groups and those that do.

trans-unit.source: If you are not using AlwaysOn and have an existing standalone SQL Server, you can upgrade to Premium Storage by using a new cloud service and storage account.
trans-unit.target: If you are not using AlwaysOn and have an existing standalone SQL Server, you can upgrade to Premium Storage by using a new cloud service and storage account.

trans-unit.source: Consider the following options:
trans-unit.target: Consider the following options:

trans-unit.source: Create a new SQL Server VM.
trans-unit.target: Create a new SQL Server VM.

trans-unit.source: You can create a new SQL Server VM that uses a Premium Storage account, as documented in New Deployments.
trans-unit.target: You can create a new SQL Server VM that uses a Premium Storage account, as documented in New Deployments.

trans-unit.source: Then backup and restore your SQL Server configuration and user databases.
trans-unit.target: Then backup and restore your SQL Server configuration and user databases.

trans-unit.source: The application will need to be updated to reference the new SQL Server if it is being accessed internally or externally.
trans-unit.target: The application will need to be updated to reference the new SQL Server if it is being accessed internally or externally.

trans-unit.source: You would need to copy all ‘out of db’ objects as if you were doing a Side by Side (SxS) SQL Server migration.
trans-unit.target: You would need to copy all ‘out of db’ objects as if you were doing a Side by Side (SxS) SQL Server migration.

trans-unit.source: This includes objects such as logins, certificates, and linked servers.
trans-unit.target: This includes objects such as logins, certificates, and linked servers.

trans-unit.source: Migrate an existing SQL Server VM.
trans-unit.target: Migrate an existing SQL Server VM.

trans-unit.source: This will require taking the SQL Server VM offline, then transferring it to a new cloud service, which includes copying all of its attached VHDs to the Premium Storage account.
trans-unit.target: This will require taking the SQL Server VM offline, then transferring it to a new cloud service, which includes copying all of its attached VHDs to the Premium Storage account.

trans-unit.source: When the VM comes online, the application will reference the server host name as before.
trans-unit.target: When the VM comes online, the application will reference the server host name as before.

trans-unit.source: Be aware that the size of the existing disk will affect the performance characteristics.
trans-unit.target: Be aware that the size of the existing disk will affect the performance characteristics.

trans-unit.source: For example, a 400 GB disk gets rounded up to a P20.
trans-unit.target: For example, a 400 GB disk gets rounded up to a P20.

trans-unit.source: If you know that you do not require that disk performance, then you could recreate the VM as a DS Series VM, and attach Premium Storage VHDs of the size/performance specification you require.
trans-unit.target: If you know that you do not require that disk performance, then you could recreate the VM as a DS Series VM, and attach Premium Storage VHDs of the size/performance specification you require.

trans-unit.source: Then you could detach and reattach the SQL DB files.

trans-unit.source: Existing Deployments that use AlwaysOn Availability Groups
trans-unit.target: Existing Deployments that use AlwaysOn Availability Groups

trans-unit.source: For existing deployments, first see the <link><linkText>Prerequisites</linkText><title></title></link> section of this topic.
trans-unit.target: For existing deployments, first see the <link><linkText>Prerequisites</linkText><title></title></link> section of this topic.

trans-unit.source: Intially in this section we will look at how AlwaysOn interacts with Azure Networking.
trans-unit.target: Intially in this section we will look at how AlwaysOn interacts with Azure Networking.

trans-unit.source: We will then break down migrations in to two scenarios: migrations where some downtime can be tolerated and migrations where you must achieve minimal downtime.
trans-unit.target: We will then break down migrations in to two scenarios: migrations where some downtime can be tolerated and migrations where you must achieve minimal downtime.

trans-unit.source: On-premises SQL Server AlwaysOn Availability Groups use a Listener on-premises that registers a virtual DNS name along with an IP address that is shared between one or more SQL Servers.
trans-unit.target: On-premises SQL Server AlwaysOn Availability Groups use a Listener on-premises that registers a virtual DNS name along with an IP address that is shared between one or more SQL Servers.

trans-unit.source: When clients connect they are routed through the listener IP to the Primary SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: When clients connect they are routed through the listener IP to the Primary SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: This is the server that owns the AlwaysOn IP resource at that time.
trans-unit.target: This is the server that owns the AlwaysOn IP resource at that time.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>DeploymentsUseAlwaysOn</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>DeploymentsUseAlwaysOn</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In Microsoft Azure you can have only one IP address assigned to a NIC on the VM, so in order to achieve the same layer of abstraction as on-premises, Azure utilizes the IP address that is assigned to the Internal/External Load Balancers (ILB/ELB).
trans-unit.target: In Microsoft Azure you can have only one IP address assigned to a NIC on the VM, so in order to achieve the same layer of abstraction as on-premises, Azure utilizes the IP address that is assigned to the Internal/External Load Balancers (ILB/ELB).

trans-unit.source: The IP resource that is shared between the servers is set to the same IP as the ILB/ELB.
trans-unit.target: The IP resource that is shared between the servers is set to the same IP as the ILB/ELB.

trans-unit.source: This is published in the DNS, and client traffic is passed through the ILB/ELB to the Primary SQL Server replica.
trans-unit.target: This is published in the DNS, and client traffic is passed through the ILB/ELB to the Primary SQL Server replica.

trans-unit.source: The ILB/ELB knows which SQL Server is primary since it uses probes to probe the AlwaysOn IP resource.
trans-unit.target: The ILB/ELB knows which SQL Server is primary since it uses probes to probe the AlwaysOn IP resource.

trans-unit.source: In the previous example, it probes each node that has an endpoint referenced by the ELB/ILB, whichever responds is the Primary SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: In the previous example, it probes each node that has an endpoint referenced by the ELB/ILB, whichever responds is the Primary SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: The ILB and ELB are both assigned to a particular Azure cloud service, therefore any cloud migration in Azure will most likely mean that the Load Balancer IP will change.
trans-unit.target: The ILB and ELB are both assigned to a particular Azure cloud service, therefore any cloud migration in Azure will most likely mean that the Load Balancer IP will change.

trans-unit.source: Migrating AlwaysOn deployments that can allow some downtime
trans-unit.target: Migrating AlwaysOn deployments that can allow some downtime

trans-unit.source: There are two strategies to migrate AlwaysOn deployments that allow for some downtime:
trans-unit.target: There are two strategies to migrate AlwaysOn deployments that allow for some downtime:

trans-unit.source: Add more secondary replicas to an existing AlwaysOn Cluster
trans-unit.target: Add more secondary replicas to an existing AlwaysOn Cluster

trans-unit.source: Migrate to a new AlwaysOn Cluster
trans-unit.target: Migrate to a new AlwaysOn Cluster

trans-unit.source: 1. Add more Secondary Replicas to an Existing AlwaysOn Cluster
trans-unit.target: 1. Add more Secondary Replicas to an Existing AlwaysOn Cluster

trans-unit.source: One strategy is to add more secondaries to the AlwaysOn Availability Group.
trans-unit.target: One strategy is to add more secondaries to the AlwaysOn Availability Group.

trans-unit.source: You need to add these into a new cloud service and update the listener with the new load balancer IP.
trans-unit.target: You need to add these into a new cloud service and update the listener with the new load balancer IP.

trans-unit.source: Points of Downtime:
trans-unit.target: Points of Downtime:

trans-unit.source: Cluster Validation.
trans-unit.target: Cluster Validation.

trans-unit.source: Testing AlwaysOn failovers for New Secondaries.
trans-unit.target: Testing AlwaysOn failovers for New Secondaries.

trans-unit.source: If you are using Windows Storage Pools within the VM for higher IO throughput, then these will be taken offline during a Full Cluster Validation.
trans-unit.target: If you are using Windows Storage Pools within the VM for higher IO throughput, then these will be taken offline during a Full Cluster Validation.

trans-unit.source: The validation test is required when you add nodes to the cluster.
trans-unit.target: The validation test is required when you add nodes to the cluster.

trans-unit.source: The time it takes to run the test can vary, so you should test this in your representative test environment to get an approximate time of how long this will take.
trans-unit.target: The time it takes to run the test can vary, so you should test this in your representative test environment to get an approximate time of how long this will take.

trans-unit.source: You should provision time where you can perform manual failover and chaos testing on the newly added nodes to ensure AlwaysOn High Availability functions as expected.
trans-unit.target: You should provision time where you can perform manual failover and chaos testing on the newly added nodes to ensure AlwaysOn High Availability functions as expected.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>DeploymentUseAlwaysOn2</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>DeploymentUseAlwaysOn2</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You should stop all instances of SQL Server where the Storage Pools are used before the Validaion runs.
trans-unit.target: You should stop all instances of SQL Server where the Storage Pools are used before the Validaion runs.

trans-unit.source: High Level Steps
trans-unit.target: High Level Steps

trans-unit.source: Create two new SQL Servers in new cloud service with attached Premium Storage.
trans-unit.target: Create two new SQL Servers in new cloud service with attached Premium Storage.

trans-unit.source: Copy over FULL backups and restore with NORECOVERY.
trans-unit.target: Copy over FULL backups and restore with NORECOVERY.

trans-unit.source: Copy over ‘out of user DB’ dependent objects, such as logins etc.
trans-unit.target: Copy over ‘out of user DB’ dependent objects, such as logins etc.

trans-unit.source: Create new a new Internal Load Balancer (ILB) or use an External Load Balancer (ELB), and then set up Load Balanced Endpoints on both new nodes.
trans-unit.target: Create new a new Internal Load Balancer (ILB) or use an External Load Balancer (ELB), and then set up Load Balanced Endpoints on both new nodes.

trans-unit.source: Check all Nodes have the correct Endpoint configuration before you continue
trans-unit.target: Check all Nodes have the correct Endpoint configuration before you continue

trans-unit.source: Stop User/Application Access to the SQL Server (if using Storage Pools).
trans-unit.target: Stop User/Application Access to the SQL Server (if using Storage Pools).

trans-unit.source: Stop SQL Server Engine Services on All Nodes (if using Storage Pools).
trans-unit.target: Stop SQL Server Engine Services on All Nodes (if using Storage Pools).

trans-unit.source: Add new Nodes to cluster and run full validation.
trans-unit.target: Add new Nodes to cluster and run full validation.

trans-unit.source: Once Validation is successful, start all SQL Server Services.
trans-unit.target: Once Validation is successful, start all SQL Server Services.

trans-unit.source: Backup Transaction logs, and restore user databases.
trans-unit.target: Backup Transaction logs, and restore user databases.

trans-unit.source: Add new nodes into the AlwaysOn Availability Group and place replication into Syncronous.
trans-unit.target: Add new nodes into the AlwaysOn Availability Group and place replication into Syncronous.

trans-unit.source: Add the IP address resource of the new Cloud Service ILB/ELB through PowerShell for AlwaysOn based on the Multi-site example in the <link><linkText>Appendix</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Add the IP address resource of the new Cloud Service ILB/ELB through PowerShell for AlwaysOn based on the Multi-site example in the <link><linkText>Appendix</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: In Windows clustering, set the Possible owners of the IP Address resource to the new nodes old.
trans-unit.target: In Windows clustering, set the Possible owners of the IP Address resource to the new nodes old.

trans-unit.source: See the ‘Adding IP Address Resource on Same Subnet’ section of the <link><linkText>Appendix</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: See the ‘Adding IP Address Resource on Same Subnet’ section of the <link><linkText>Appendix</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Failover to one of the new nodes.
trans-unit.target: Failover to one of the new nodes.

trans-unit.source: Make the new nodes Auto Failover Partners and test failovers.
trans-unit.target: Make the new nodes Auto Failover Partners and test failovers.

trans-unit.source: Remove original nodes from Availability Group.
trans-unit.target: Remove original nodes from Availability Group.

trans-unit.source: Advantages
trans-unit.target: Advantages

trans-unit.source: New SQL Servers can be tested (SQL Server and Application) before they are added to AlwaysOn.
trans-unit.target: New SQL Servers can be tested (SQL Server and Application) before they are added to AlwaysOn.

trans-unit.source: You can change the VM size and customize the storage to your exact requirements.
trans-unit.target: You can change the VM size and customize the storage to your exact requirements.

trans-unit.source: However, it would be beneficial to keep all the SQL file paths the same.
trans-unit.target: However, it would be beneficial to keep all the SQL file paths the same.

trans-unit.source: You can control when the transfer of the DB backups to the Secondary Replicas are started.
trans-unit.target: You can control when the transfer of the DB backups to the Secondary Replicas are started.

trans-unit.source: This differs from using Azure Start-AzureStorageBlobCopy commandlet to copy VHDs, because that is an asynchronous copy.
trans-unit.target: This differs from using Azure Start-AzureStorageBlobCopy commandlet to copy VHDs, because that is an asynchronous copy.

trans-unit.source: Disadvantages
trans-unit.target: Disadvantages

trans-unit.source: When using Windows Storage Pools, there is Cluster downtime during the Full Cluster Validation for the new additional nodes.
trans-unit.target: When using Windows Storage Pools, there is Cluster downtime during the Full Cluster Validation for the new additional nodes.

trans-unit.source: Depending on the SQL Server Version and the existing number of secondary replicas, you might not be able to add more secondary replicas without removing existing secondaries.
trans-unit.target: Depending on the SQL Server Version and the existing number of secondary replicas, you might not be able to add more secondary replicas without removing existing secondaries.

trans-unit.source: There could be long SQL data transfer time while setting up the secondaries.
trans-unit.target: There could be long SQL data transfer time while setting up the secondaries.

trans-unit.source: There is additional cost during migration while you have new machines running in paralell.
trans-unit.target: There is additional cost during migration while you have new machines running in paralell.

trans-unit.source: 2. Migrate to a New AlwaysOn Cluster
trans-unit.target: 2. Migrate to a New AlwaysOn Cluster

trans-unit.source: Another strategy is to create a brand new AlwaysOn Cluster with brand new nodes in new cloud service and then redirect the clients to use it.
trans-unit.target: Another strategy is to create a brand new AlwaysOn Cluster with brand new nodes in new cloud service and then redirect the clients to use it.

trans-unit.source: Points of Downtime
trans-unit.target: Points of Downtime

trans-unit.source: There is downtime when you transfer applications and users to the new AlwaysOn listener.
trans-unit.target: There is downtime when you transfer applications and users to the new AlwaysOn listener.

trans-unit.source: The downtime depends on:
trans-unit.target: The downtime depends on:

trans-unit.source: The time taken to restore final transaction log backups to databases on new servers.
trans-unit.target: The time taken to restore final transaction log backups to databases on new servers.

trans-unit.source: The time taken to update client applications to use new AlwaysOn listener.
trans-unit.target: The time taken to update client applications to use new AlwaysOn listener.

trans-unit.source: Advantages
trans-unit.target: Advantages

trans-unit.source: You can test the actual production environment, SQL Server, and OS build changes.
trans-unit.target: You can test the actual production environment, SQL Server, and OS build changes.

trans-unit.source: You have the option to customize the storage and to potentially reduce size of VM.
trans-unit.target: You have the option to customize the storage and to potentially reduce size of VM.

trans-unit.source: This could result in cost reduction.
trans-unit.target: This could result in cost reduction.

trans-unit.source: You can update your SQL Server build or version during this process.
trans-unit.target: You can update your SQL Server build or version during this process.

trans-unit.source: You can also upgrade the Operating System.
trans-unit.target: You can also upgrade the Operating System.

trans-unit.source: The previous AlwaysOn Cluster can act as a solid rollback target.
trans-unit.target: The previous AlwaysOn Cluster can act as a solid rollback target.

trans-unit.source: Disadvantages
trans-unit.target: Disadvantages

trans-unit.source: You need to change the DNS name of the listener if you want both AlwaysOn clusters running simultaneously.
trans-unit.target: You need to change the DNS name of the listener if you want both AlwaysOn clusters running simultaneously.

trans-unit.source: This adds administration overhead during the migration as client application strings must reflect the new Listener name.
trans-unit.target: This adds administration overhead during the migration as client application strings must reflect the new Listener name.

trans-unit.source: You must implement a synchronization mechanism between the two environments to keep them as close as possible to minimize the final synchronization requirements before migration.
trans-unit.target: You must implement a synchronization mechanism between the two environments to keep them as close as possible to minimize the final synchronization requirements before migration.

trans-unit.source: There is added cost during migration while you have the new environment running.
trans-unit.target: There is added cost during migration while you have the new environment running.

trans-unit.source: Migrating AlwaysOn Deployments for Minimal Downtime
trans-unit.target: Migrating AlwaysOn Deployments for Minimal Downtime

trans-unit.source: There are two strategies for migrating AlwaysOn deployments for minimal downtime:
trans-unit.target: There are two strategies for migrating AlwaysOn deployments for minimal downtime:

trans-unit.source: Utilize an Existing Secondary: Single-Site
trans-unit.target: Utilize an Existing Secondary: Single-Site

trans-unit.source: Utilize Existing Secondary Replica(s): Multi-Site
trans-unit.target: Utilize Existing Secondary Replica(s): Multi-Site

trans-unit.source: 1. Utilize an Existing Secondary: Single-Site
trans-unit.target: 1. Utilize an Existing Secondary: Single-Site

trans-unit.source: One strategy for minimal downtime is to take an existing cloud secondary and remove it from the current cloud service.
trans-unit.target: One strategy for minimal downtime is to take an existing cloud secondary and remove it from the current cloud service.

trans-unit.source: Then copy the VHDs to the new Premium Storage account, and create the VM in the new cloud service.
trans-unit.target: Then copy the VHDs to the new Premium Storage account, and create the VM in the new cloud service.

trans-unit.source: Then update the listener in clustering and failover.
trans-unit.target: Then update the listener in clustering and failover.

trans-unit.source: Points of Downtime
trans-unit.target: Points of Downtime

trans-unit.source: There is downtime when you update the final node with the Load Balanaced endpoint.
trans-unit.target: There is downtime when you update the final node with the Load Balanaced endpoint.

trans-unit.source: Your client reconnection might be delayed depending on your client/DNS configuration.
trans-unit.target: Your client reconnection might be delayed depending on your client/DNS configuration.

trans-unit.source: There is additional downtime if you choose to take the AlwaysOn Cluster group offline to swap out the IP addresses.
trans-unit.target: There is additional downtime if you choose to take the AlwaysOn Cluster group offline to swap out the IP addresses.

trans-unit.source: You can avoid this by using an OR dependancy and Possible Owners for the added IP Address resource.
trans-unit.target: You can avoid this by using an OR dependancy and Possible Owners for the added IP Address resource.

trans-unit.source: See the ‘Adding IP Address Resource on Same Subnet’ section of the <link><linkText>Appendix</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: See the ‘Adding IP Address Resource on Same Subnet’ section of the <link><linkText>Appendix</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: When you want the added node to partake in as an AlwaysOn Failover Partner, you need to add an Azure Endpoint with a reference to the Load Balanced Set.
trans-unit.target: When you want the added node to partake in as an AlwaysOn Failover Partner, you need to add an Azure Endpoint with a reference to the Load Balanced Set.

trans-unit.source: When you run the Add-AzureEndpoint command to do this, current connections to remain open, but new connections to the listener will not be able to be established until the load balancer has updated.
trans-unit.target: When you run the Add-AzureEndpoint command to do this, current connections to remain open, but new connections to the listener will not be able to be established until the load balancer has updated.

trans-unit.source: Advantages
trans-unit.target: Advantages

trans-unit.source: No extra cost incurred during migration.
trans-unit.target: No extra cost incurred during migration.

trans-unit.source: A one-to-one migration.
trans-unit.target: A one-to-one migration.

trans-unit.source: Reduced complexity.
trans-unit.target: Reduced complexity.

trans-unit.source: Allows for increased IOPS from Premium Storage SKUs.
trans-unit.target: Allows for increased IOPS from Premium Storage SKUs.

trans-unit.source: When the disks are detached from the VM and copied to the new cloud service, a 3rd party tool can be used to increase the VHD size, which provides higher throughputs.
trans-unit.target: When the disks are detached from the VM and copied to the new cloud service, a 3rd party tool can be used to increase the VHD size, which provides higher throughputs.

trans-unit.target: For increasing VHD sizes, see this <link><linkText>forum discussion</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.target: Disadvantages

trans-unit.source: There is a temporary loss of HA and DR during migration.
trans-unit.target: There is a temporary loss of HA and DR during migration.

trans-unit.source: As this is a 1:1 migration, you will have to use a minimum VM size that will support your number of VHDs, so you might not be able to downsize your VMs.
trans-unit.target: As this is a 1:1 migration, you will have to use a minimum VM size that will support your number of VHDs, so you might not be able to downsize your VMs.

trans-unit.source: This scenario would use the Azure Start-AzureStorageBlobCopy commandlet, which is asynchronous.
trans-unit.target: This scenario would use the Azure Start-AzureStorageBlobCopy commandlet, which is asynchronous.

trans-unit.source: There is no SLA on copy completion.
trans-unit.target: There is no SLA on copy completion.

trans-unit.source: The time of the copies varies, while this depends on wait in queue it will also depend on the amount of data to transfer.
trans-unit.target: The time of the copies varies, while this depends on wait in queue it will also depend on the amount of data to transfer.

trans-unit.source: The copy time increases if the transfer is going to another Azure data center that supports Premium Storage in another region.
trans-unit.target: The copy time increases if the transfer is going to another Azure data center that supports Premium Storage in another region.

trans-unit.source: If you just have 2 nodes, consider a possible mitigation in case the copy takes longer than in testing.
trans-unit.target: If you just have 2 nodes, consider a possible mitigation in case the copy takes longer than in testing.

trans-unit.target: Run the migration outside of Azure scheduled maintenance.

trans-unit.target: 2. Utilize Existing Secondary Replica(s): Multi-Site

trans-unit.source: If you have nodes in more than one Azure datacenter (DC) or if you have a hybrid environment, then you can use an AlwaysOn configuration in this environment to minimize downtime.
trans-unit.target: If you have nodes in more than one Azure datacenter (DC) or if you have a hybrid environment, then you can use an AlwaysOn configuration in this environment to minimize downtime.

trans-unit.source: The approach is to change the AlwaysOn synchronization to Synchronous for the on-premises or secondary Azure DC, and then failover over to that SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: The approach is to change the AlwaysOn synchronization to Synchronous for the on-premises or secondary Azure DC, and then failover over to that SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: Then copy the VHDs to a Premium Storage account, and redeploy the machine into a new cloud service.

trans-unit.target: Points of Downtime

trans-unit.source: The downtime consists of the time to failover to the alternative DC and back.
trans-unit.target: The downtime consists of the time to failover to the alternative DC and back.

trans-unit.source: It also depends on your client/DNS configuration and your client reconnection may be delayed.

trans-unit.source: Advantages
trans-unit.target: Advantages

trans-unit.source: You can utilize existing infrastructure.
trans-unit.target: You can utilize existing infrastructure.

trans-unit.source: You have the option to pre-upgrade the Azure storage on the DR Azure DC first.
trans-unit.target: You have the option to pre-upgrade the Azure storage on the DR Azure DC first.

trans-unit.source: The DR Azure DC storage can be reconfigured.
trans-unit.target: The DR Azure DC storage can be reconfigured.

trans-unit.source: There is a minimum of two failovers during migration, excluding test failovers.
trans-unit.target: There is a minimum of two failovers during migration, excluding test failovers.

trans-unit.source: You do not need to move SQL Server data with backup and restore.
trans-unit.target: You do not need to move SQL Server data with backup and restore.

trans-unit.target: Disadvantages

trans-unit.source: Depending on client access to SQL Server, there might be increased latency when SQL Server is running in an alternative DC to the application.
trans-unit.target: Depending on client access to SQL Server, there might be increased latency when SQL Server is running in an alternative DC to the application.

trans-unit.source: The copy time of VHDs to Premium storage could be long.

trans-unit.source: This might affect your decision on whether to keep the node in the Availability Group.
trans-unit.target: This might affect your decision on whether to keep the node in the Availability Group.

trans-unit.source: Therefore this could grow significantly.

trans-unit.source: This scenario would use the Azure Start-AzureStorageBlobCopy commandlet, which is asynchronous.
trans-unit.target: This scenario would use the Azure Start-AzureStorageBlobCopy commandlet, which is asynchronous.

trans-unit.source: There is no SLA on completion.
trans-unit.target: There is no SLA on completion.

trans-unit.source: The time of the copies varies, while this depends on wait in queue, it will also depend on the amount of data to transfer.
trans-unit.target: The time of the copies varies, while this depends on wait in queue, it will also depend on the amount of data to transfer.

trans-unit.source: Therefore you just have one node in your 2nd data center, you should take mitigation steps in case the copy takes longer than in testing.
trans-unit.target: Therefore you just have one node in your 2nd data center, you should take mitigation steps in case the copy takes longer than in testing.

trans-unit.source: This could include the following ideas.
trans-unit.target: This could include the following ideas.

trans-unit.source: Add a temporary 2nd SQL node for HA before the migration with agreed downtime.
trans-unit.target: Add a temporary 2nd SQL node for HA before the migration with agreed downtime.

trans-unit.source: Run the migration outside of Azure scheduled maintenance.
trans-unit.target: Run the migration outside of Azure scheduled maintenance.

trans-unit.source: Ensure you have configured your cluster quorum correctly.
trans-unit.target: Ensure you have configured your cluster quorum correctly.

trans-unit.source: High Level Steps
trans-unit.target: High Level Steps

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Multisite2</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Multisite2</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Make the on-premises / alternate Azure DC the SQL Server Primary, and make it the other Auto Failover Partner (AFP).
trans-unit.target: Make the on-premises / alternate Azure DC the SQL Server Primary, and make it the other Auto Failover Partner (AFP).

trans-unit.source: Gather disk configuration information from SQL2, and remove the node (do not delete attached VHDs).
trans-unit.target: Gather disk configuration information from SQL2, and remove the node (do not delete attached VHDs).

trans-unit.source: Create a Premium Storage account and copy VHDs from the Standard Storage account.
trans-unit.target: Create a Premium Storage account and copy VHDs from the Standard Storage account.

trans-unit.source: Create a new cloud service and create the SQL2 VM with its Premiums Storage disks attached.
trans-unit.target: Create a new cloud service and create the SQL2 VM with its Premiums Storage disks attached.

trans-unit.source: Configure ILB / ELB and add Endpoints.
trans-unit.target: Configure ILB / ELB and add Endpoints.

trans-unit.source: Update the AlwaysOn Listener with new ILB / ELB IP address and test failover.
trans-unit.target: Update the AlwaysOn Listener with new ILB / ELB IP address and test failover.

trans-unit.source: Check the DNS configuration.
trans-unit.target: Check the DNS configuration.

trans-unit.source: Change the AFP to SQL2, and then migrate SQL1 and go through steps 2 – 5.
trans-unit.target: Change the AFP to SQL2, and then migrate SQL1 and go through steps 2 – 5.

trans-unit.source: Test failovers.
trans-unit.target: Test failovers.

trans-unit.source: Switch the AFP back to SQL1 and SQL2
trans-unit.target: Switch the AFP back to SQL1 and SQL2

trans-unit.source: Step 4: DNS Configuration
trans-unit.target: Step 4: DNS Configuration

trans-unit.source: To implement a smooth transition depends on how DNS is being utilised and updated.
trans-unit.target: To implement a smooth transition depends on how DNS is being utilised and updated.

trans-unit.source: When AlwaysOn is installed, it creates a Windows Cluster Resource group, if you open Failover Cluster Manager, you will see that at a minimum it will have three resources, the two that the document refers to are:
trans-unit.target: When AlwaysOn is installed, it creates a Windows Cluster Resource group, if you open Failover Cluster Manager, you will see that at a minimum it will have three resources, the two that the document refers to are:

trans-unit.source: Virtual Network Name (VNN) – This is the DNS name that client connect to when wanting to connect to SQL Servers via AlwaysOn.
trans-unit.target: Virtual Network Name (VNN) – This is the DNS name that client connect to when wanting to connect to SQL Servers via AlwaysOn.

trans-unit.source: IP Address Resource – This is the IP address that associated with the VNN, you can have more than one, and in a multisite configuration you will have an IP address per site/subnet.
trans-unit.target: IP Address Resource – This is the IP address that associated with the VNN, you can have more than one, and in a multisite configuration you will have an IP address per site/subnet.

trans-unit.source: When connecting to SQL Sevrer, the SQL Server Client driver will retrieve the DNS records associated with the listener and try to connect to each AlwaysOn associated IP address, below we discuss some factors that can influence this.
trans-unit.target: When connecting to SQL Sevrer, the SQL Server Client driver will retrieve the DNS records associated with the listener and try to connect to each AlwaysOn associated IP address, below we discuss some factors that can influence this.

trans-unit.source: The number of concurrent DNS records that are associated with the listener name depends not only on the number of IP addresses associated, but the ‘RegisterAllIpProviders’setting in Failover Clustering for the AlwaysON VNN resource.
trans-unit.target: The number of concurrent DNS records that are associated with the listener name depends not only on the number of IP addresses associated, but the ‘RegisterAllIpProviders’setting in Failover Clustering for the AlwaysON VNN resource.

trans-unit.source: When you deploy AlwaysOn in Azure there are different steps to create the Listener and IP Addresses, you have to manually configure the ‘RegisterAllIpProviders’ to 1, this is different to an on premise AlwaysOn deployment where it is already set to 1.
trans-unit.target: When you deploy AlwaysOn in Azure there are different steps to create the Listener and IP Addresses, you have to manually configure the ‘RegisterAllIpProviders’ to 1, this is different to an on premise AlwaysOn deployment where it is already set to 1.

trans-unit.source: If ‘RegisterAllIpProviders’ is 0, then you will only see one DNS record in DNS associated with the Listener:
trans-unit.target: If ‘RegisterAllIpProviders’ is 0, then you will only see one DNS record in DNS associated with the Listener:

trans-unit.target: <linkText>Appendix4</linkText>

trans-unit.target: If ‘RegisterAllIpProviders’ is 1:

trans-unit.target: <linkText>Appendix5</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The code below will dump out the VNN settings and set it for you, please note, for the change to take effect you will need to take the the VNN offline and turn it back online, this taking the Listener offline causing client connectivity disruption.
trans-unit.target: The code below will dump out the VNN settings and set it for you, please note, for the change to take effect you will need to take the the VNN offline and turn it back online, this taking the Listener offline causing client connectivity disruption.

trans-unit.source: In a later migration step you will need to update the AlwaysOn listener with an updated IP address that will reference a load balancer, this will involve an IP Address resource removal and addition.
trans-unit.target: In a later migration step you will need to update the AlwaysOn listener with an updated IP address that will reference a load balancer, this will involve an IP Address resource removal and addition.

trans-unit.source: After the IP update, you need to ensure the new IP address has been updated in DNS Zone and that the clients are updating their local DNS cache.
trans-unit.target: After the IP update, you need to ensure the new IP address has been updated in DNS Zone and that the clients are updating their local DNS cache.

trans-unit.source: If you clients reside in a different network segment and reference a different DNS server, you need to consider what happens about DNS Zone Transfer during the migration, as the application reconnect time will be constrained by at least the Zone Transfer Time of any new IP addresses for the listener.
trans-unit.target: If you clients reside in a different network segment and reference a different DNS server, you need to consider what happens about DNS Zone Transfer during the migration, as the application reconnect time will be constrained by at least the Zone Transfer Time of any new IP addresses for the listener.

trans-unit.source: If you are under time constraint here, you should discuss and test forcing an incremental zone transfer with your Windows teams, and also put the DNS host record to a lower Time To Live (TTL), so the clients update.
trans-unit.target: If you are under time constraint here, you should discuss and test forcing an incremental zone transfer with your Windows teams, and also put the DNS host record to a lower Time To Live (TTL), so the clients update.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>Incremental Zone Transfers</linkText><title></title></link> and <link><linkText>Start-DnsServerZoneTransfer</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>Incremental Zone Transfers</linkText><title></title></link> and <link><linkText>Start-DnsServerZoneTransfer</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: By default the TTL for DNS Record that is associated with the Listener in AlwaysOn in Azure is 1200 seconds.
trans-unit.target: By default the TTL for DNS Record that is associated with the Listener in AlwaysOn in Azure is 1200 seconds.

trans-unit.source: You may wish to reduce this if you are under time constraint during your migration to ensure the clients update their DNS with the updated IP address for the listener.
trans-unit.target: You may wish to reduce this if you are under time constraint during your migration to ensure the clients update their DNS with the updated IP address for the listener.

trans-unit.target: Please note, the lower the ‘HostRecordTTL’, a higher amount of DNS traffic will occur.

trans-unit.target: Client Application Settings

trans-unit.source: If your SQL client application supports the .Net 4.5 SQLClient, then you can use ‘MULTISUBNETFAILOVER=TRUE’ keyword, this is recommended to be applied as it allows for faster connection to SQL AlwaysOn Availability Group during failover.
trans-unit.target: If your SQL client application supports the .Net 4.5 SQLClient, then you can use ‘MULTISUBNETFAILOVER=TRUE’ keyword, this is recommended to be applied as it allows for faster connection to SQL AlwaysOn Availability Group during failover.

trans-unit.source: It enumerates through all IP addresses associated with the AlwaysOn listener in parallel, and performs a more aggressive TCP connection retry speed during a failover.
trans-unit.target: It enumerates through all IP addresses associated with the AlwaysOn listener in parallel, and performs a more aggressive TCP connection retry speed during a failover.

trans-unit.source: For more information regarding the settings above, please see <link><linkText>MultiSubnetFailover Keyword and Associated Features</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information regarding the settings above, please see <link><linkText>MultiSubnetFailover Keyword and Associated Features</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: As you are going to be taking out at least one SQL Server down at a time, you should modify the cluster quorum setting, if using File Share Witnes (FSW) with 2 nodes, you should set the quorum to allow node majority and utilise dynamic voting, and this is to allow for a single node to remain standing.
trans-unit.target: As you are going to be taking out at least one SQL Server down at a time, you should modify the cluster quorum setting, if using File Share Witnes (FSW) with 2 nodes, you should set the quorum to allow node majority and utilise dynamic voting, and this is to allow for a single node to remain standing.

trans-unit.source: For more information on managing and configuring the cluster quorum, please see <link><linkText>Configure and Manage the Quorum in a Windows Server 2012 Failover Cluster</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on managing and configuring the cluster quorum, please see <link><linkText>Configure and Manage the Quorum in a Windows Server 2012 Failover Cluster</linkText><title></title></link>.
